content: When AI makes rewriting code and understanding large foreign codebases cheap, the incentive to rely on deep dependency trees will collapse, leading to a return of software monoliths.
Reducing software dependencies offers benefits such as a smaller attack surface for supply chain threats, smaller packaged software, improved performance, and faster boot times.

The Lindy effect, which suggests that long-standing things persist for good reason, will weaken in a world where AI agents can develop software from first principles and understand codebases effortlessly.
In an AI-dominated software world, formal verification is essential, not optional, due to the persistence of unknown unknowns.
